doc.source_uri: 2025-08-29/China Pacific Insurance Group - H Earnings growth in 1H25 but the absence of an interim dividend as anticipated may limi_2025-08-29

passages.text: Earnings growth in 1H25, but the absence of an interim dividend (as anticipated) may limit upside

CPIC delivered a relatively solid set of 1H25 results, with Rmb 27.9B (11% oya) in 1H25 NP (vs. JPM: Rmb 25.6B), Rmb 9.5B (6% oya) in new business value (vs. JPM: Rmb 10.8B), and a strong core solvency ratio of \(190\%\) \((+8\% p\) YTD). Reflecting these solid figures, we have raised our PT from HK\$27 to HK\$32. However, we have not upgraded the stock to OW. This is for three reasons. Firstly, CPIC did not propose an interim dividend. Secondly, the company's dividend policy is linked to OPAT growth (1H25: \(7\%\) oya), and we see limited upside on the \(2.5\%\) FY25E consensus dividend yield or DPS (Rmb 1.13/share, \(5\%\) oya), considering earnings seasonality and reserve growth trends. Thirdly, the life sales quality appears less robust compared to major peers (China Life/Ping An), as the 1H25 life sales have been significantly supported by bancassurance (1H25 first-year premium: agent (Rmb22.6B, \(- 7.7\%\) oya) vs. bancassurance (Rmb29.0B, \(95.6\%\) oya)). As such, we prefer larger-cap insurers (China Life-H/Ping An-H) over CPIC-H.

Solid 1H results underpinned by sound capital. In addition to earnings growth, we observe that the overall results appear robust across key metrics. These include: (1) positive new business value (Rmb 9.5B, \(6\%\) oya), based on new assumptions (or \(32\%\) oya on a like-for-like basis), (2) positive embedded value growth ( \(5\%\) YTD) and contractual service margin growth ( \(1\%\) YTD), and (3) improvement in non- life underwriting (1H25 combined ratio: \(96.3\%\) \(- 0.8\%\) oya). The group's core solvency ratio stands at \(190\%\) \((+8\%\) YTD). We believe that this fundamental growth appears to adequately support the YTD stock outperformance ( \(42\%\) vs. HSI: \(25\%\) ) or 9x FY26E P/E with a \(3\%\) yield.

Absence of an interim dividend proposal is noteworthy. Unlike previous years, China's SOE insurers, such as China Life, PICC Group, and PICC P&C, are beginning to place greater emphasis on shareholder returns, with double- digit interim dividend increases this reporting season with higher earnings growth. They are trading at an 8x FY26E P/E with a \(3\%\) yield. As the market may adjust the currently conservative dividend forecasts for SOE insurers, the yield differential is expected to narrow. Additionally, Ping An- H offers a \(6\%\) yield, accompanied by multiple signs of a fundamental turnaround- (link). As such, in our view, for CPIC to achieve stock outperformance for the rest of year, it may need to consider providing more aggressive year- end guidance.

Worth monitoring the book value & life sales trend. The company's book value has declined to Rmb313B \((- 2\%\) YTD), following liability reserve adjustment seemingly due to the lower risk- free rate. Additionally, it will be interesting to observe whether a similar scale of life sales volume can be sustained following the further reduction in the guaranteed rate this Sep to \(2.0\%\) (current: \(2.5\%\) ) for non- par policies.
Price Target (Jun- 26): HK\$32.00 Prior (Jun- 26): HK\$27.00

We forecast \(10\%\) oya growth in FY25 new business value. As asset risk seems to be receding, we are not concerned about the high level of stress on investment assets (portion of nonstandard assets: \(10\%\) of total AUM as of Jun- 25). Also, regulatory control on the bancassurance channel has been helpful in achieving a higher loading margin. Hence, following the government call for adding more equity holdings and a large portion of the equity holdings classified as FVPL, CPIC Group may be more volatile compared to major peers in terms of net profit if the equity market turns more volatile. Hence, we remain cautious on the company's solvency capital/dividend outlook for the next three years due to the potential adverse financial impact from a falling bond yield and the lagging business recovery in the agent channel.

Our Jun- 26 PT of HK\$32 is based on a SOTP valuation (methodology unchanged). We use a P/E approach for the Life business (based on 8x FY26E) and the Non- Life business (based on 4x FY26E) to arrive at our price target.
Macro:HSI Volatility Index0.130.40JPM China A-shares Sentiment-0.130.35JPM EM Currency(EMCI) Fixing-0.17-0.21Quant Styles:Growth-0.29-0.40Momentum-0.13-0.35Size-0.17-0.25

**Earnings.** The company printed Rmb27.9B in net profit, implying 11% oya growth, arriving above our expectations of 2% oya growth. The earnings growth was supported by investment income which rose 214%. However, the companies' core earnings also remained steady with Group OPAT at Rmb19.9B (7% oya).

**NBV.** 1H25 new business value was Rmb9.5B, which represented 32% oya growth on like-for-like basis, based on new assumptions. Although we view the positive NBV growth positively, we note that the quality of new life sales was not entirely optimal, with the majority of the growth being attributed to the bancassurance channel's substantial growth, while the agent channel FYP shrank (1H25 first-year premium: agent (Rmb22.6B,-7.7% oya) vs. bancassurance (Rmb29.0B, 96% oya)).

**Reserve growth trend.** We also note the positive growth in embedded value and contractual service margin (CSM) balance in 1H25, which bodes well for future profit generation. However, a decline in book value due (-2% oya), seemingly due to the lower interest rate, is worth monitoring, despite the company's solid capital position (1H25 core solvency ratio of CPIC Group/Life/P&C:190%/136%/196%).

**Non-Life underwriting.** The company's 1H25 combined ratio (96.3%, -0.8%p oya) was above our expectations (96.8%). The improvement came from the enhanced profitability in the automobile and commercial segments, where the combined ratios stood at 95.3%/92.8% (-1.8%p/-1.3%p oya), respectively.

Source: CPIC 1H24-1H25 interim report.
